titleInfo.title: Letter from Isaac Morgan Leihy and his wife Ruth Leihy to P.J. Williamson, 1869 December 01

location.physicalLocation: Special Collections Division of the Nashville Public Library, 615 Church Street, Nashville, Tennessee, 37219

mods.abstract: A letter from Isaac Morgan Leihy and his wife Ruth Leihy to their son-in-law and Dutch immigrant, Peter J. Williamson. In 1862 Williamson enlisted as a Private in the 1st Wisconsin Cavalry, Company F and was ultimately promoted to Full 1st Lieutenant. During the war, Williamson's regiment was involved in scouting and raids in Missouri and Arkansas and saw battle in the Middle Tennessee, Chickamauga, and Atlanta campaigns. After the war, he and his family settled in Nashville, where he became an architect. Williamson's wife, Eunice, spent time in California nursing her health. In this letter from San Bernardino, California, the Leihy's write of Eunice's time spent in their care. They received his letter to her dated November 11th, 1869, and had not forwarded it because they think Eunice to be on her way home to Nashville. They mention that they know nothing about William not answering his letters and hope no unpleasant feelings have been created due to her stay there. They express their sympathy toward Williamson and the children for their loneliness during Eunice's absence. Isaac and Ruth report their health as "tolerable" and mention returning from a trip to San Diego. They discuss the possibility of moving to Los Angeles County in the future and speak of their religious beliefs. They report an encounter in San Diego in relation to the keeper of the Bay View Hotel and how poor he seemed. In closing they send Waldo and Irwin's love to Johnny and Willy and ask Williamson to write back concerning Eunice's arrival home. Forms part of the Peter J. Williamson Letters. 1 letter : col. ; 5 x 8 in.
